accordion.accordion_title: What is lisinopril and how does it work?
accordion.accordion_intro: Lisinopril is a type of medication known as an ACE inhibitor, and is used to primarily treat high blood pressure. It does so by blocking enzymes  that cause your blood pressure to rise. It is known as an antihypertensive drug.

accordion.accordion_title: What are the uses for lisinopril?
accordion.accordion_intro: Lisinopril is used to treat high blood pressure, which can help prevent a variety of conditions including strokes, heart attacks, kidney problems, and heart failure.

Lisinopril is available as a tablet or liquid solution and should be taken as directed by a doctor. It can be taken with, or without food and is taken once a day. Tablet forms come in doses varying from 10mg to 40mg.

accordion.accordion_title: What are the side effects and risks of lisinopril?
accordion.accordion_intro:
As your body adjusts to the medication, lisinopril may cause:

  • Dizziness
  • Lightheadedness
  • Tiredness
  • Headache
  • Dry cough
accordion.accordion_content: Additionally, some users may experience high potassium levels, fainting, muscle weakness, or a slow heartbeat. It can also cause liver issues (severe nausea/vomiting, yellowing of skin/eyes, dark urine, abdominal pain). If any of these severe side effects occur, it is important to speak to a doctor as soon as possible.

accordion.accordion_intro: Lisinopril should not be taken during pregnancy, unless there are no other alternatives and the benefits outweigh the risks to the fetus. Allergic reactions are rare.
